result.text: As someone with Asperger‚Äôs, I instinctively question everything, unable to feign virtue in actions I doubt or to support efforts that seem misaligned with true faith. I give to my church, trusting their discernment, but I withhold from those I suspect misuse funds or enable sin under the guise of charity. When it comes to missions, I rely entirely on my church‚Äôs judgment, wary of organizations that twist God‚Äôs Word for profit, luring souls with false promises of salvation while paving a path to ruin. Yet, I‚Äôve discovered Christians Teaching Christians (CTC Worldwide), a remarkable program that echoes the disciples‚Äô footsteps (Acts 14:21-23), equipping indigenous leaders in places like Africa and India with pure biblical teaching through immersive in-person, virtual, and cohort-based mentoring. By anchoring its work in gospel truth and rigorous training, CTC curbs corruption of Scripture, empowering locals to preach, plant churches, and disciple others in their own cultural context, fostering self-sustaining faith communities free from Western crutches (2 Timothy 2:2). For those that want to give, who want to know what their money is doing, who want to see tangible results leading to the True gospel being spread and watch it as it transforms lives... there is no better place to give.

result.post_image_description: First image displays a graphical user interface for Customer Service Setup with nodes connected in a workflow: Return Agent, Quality Guard, Chat Agent, and Guardrail Agent, shown in a light blue and orange themed editor window. result.text:
Low-code is nice, but if I had to bet on a future, it‚Äôs code-based orchestration + coding agents to let anyone bridge that gap.

OpenAI‚Äôs AgentKit (left img) lets you get started building various flows, like comparing docs, or a basic assistant. Once you need to encode more domain-specific logic/fetch from a data source/create a longer-running agent, you‚Äôll need to export to code and maintain your own workflow.

I‚Äôm bullish on building advanced agents over your data that live natively on top of a code-based orchestration framework (right two images). We‚Äôve built core tools in @llama_index to help enable building code-based agentic workflows and then deploying them. You can easily get started through a vibe-coding tool or through our templates, but then you get the full flexibility to add whatever you want on top. You get the underlying benefits of agentic orchestration: state management, checkpointing, human-in-the-loop.

We‚Äôve also been super deep in coding tools like Claude Code/Cursor/Codex to make sure you‚Äôre able to build these automations super easily.

With our latest alpha release of LlamaAgents, you can build whatever workflow you want in code and deploy it as an e2e agent on LlamaCloud! Come check it out üëá

https://t.co/o3nMGoQRjS

result.post_image_description: First image shows a screenshot of a visual workflow builder interface with nodes and edges connected in a graph-like structure on a light blue background, titled Not Another Workflow Builder from LangChain blog dated October 2023, including text about common requests for visual builders and mentions of LangFlow, Flowise, n8n. Second image displays text explaining issues with visual workflow builders, numbered points on lack of low barrier to entry for non-technical users and complexity management leading to messy nodes and edges. Third image features a table on the squeeze of no-code agent flows with complexity levels low medium high and best solutions like no-code agent, no-code workflow, workflow code, plus discussion on agents being easier to create than workflows. Fourth image discusses democratizing LLM powered workflow builders mentioning companies like n8n Flowise LangFlow Gumpool, and interesting problems like making reliable good agents in no-code way and improving code generation models.

result.text:
Never forget how this medical scandal began.¬†

Back in the 1980s, a small group of trans activists hatched a plot: to take an absurd, illogical overvalued belief‚Äîthat being transgender is innate, natural, healthy‚Äîand force all of society to live in a fictional world built on it.

Given the sheer audacity of that plot, there must have been people who said it couldn‚Äôt be done. But if such voices existed, they were ignored. And the activists pressed on until they succeeded in nothing less than reshaping reality itself.

And they didn‚Äôt just persuade people to politely look the other way.

They rallied good, decent people to march in the streets demanding that teenagers sacrifice their health, their fertility, and their sexual function in the name of this belief.

They convinced governments to write laws based on a non-existent, fictional concept.

They enlisted well-meaning teachers to poison the minds of a generation with absurd lies.

And they drove doctors to amputate healthy organs and call it medicine.

If they could succeed in creating that false reality, then surely we can succeed in restoring truth. 

Because our cause is not built on lies but on logic and reason. Not on ideology but on sound ethical principles. Not on harm but on healing.

My talk at @genspect‚Äôs conference in Albuquerque calls for the complete rejection of this dangerous belief. 

Only by restoring truth and reality can we actually protect vulnerable people from this medical crime.

result.text:
Sam Altman on Sora, Energy, and Building an AI Empire

From GPT-5 to Sora, OpenAI has been making a dizzying amount of bets recently. It now acts as a frontier AGI research lab, a big tech product company with nearly a billion users, and a driver of the largest infrastructure buildout in history, all in one - plus, it‚Äôs made partnerships with Microsoft, Nvidia, Oracle, AMD, SoftBank, Oracle, and even the US government.

We talked to Sam Altman about the core thesis bringing OpenAI‚Äôs bets together, why they released Sora, how they use models internally, the most informative evals for assessing AI progress, and where we‚Äôre going from here.

00:00  Introduction
00:41  OpenAI‚Äôs vision
08:01  Human-AI interfaces
09:28  AI scientists and scientific progress
17:52  Sam's operating lessons
28:33  Copyright and open source
43:03  AI talent wars
45:33  Advice for founders

ÁÑ∂ËÄåÔºåËøôÁßçÂü∫‰∫é‚ÄúÈ¢ÑÊµã‚ÄùÁöÑÊ®°ÂºèÂæàÂø´Â∞±Ëß¶ÂèäÂÖ∂Âõ∫ÊúâÁöÑÂ§©Ëä±Êùø„ÄÇÂΩì‰ªªÂä°ÁöÑÂ§çÊùÇÂ∫¶Ë∂ÖË∂ä‰∫ÜÂçï‰∏ÄÊñá‰ª∂ÔºåÈúÄË¶ÅËøõË°åË∑®ÁõÆÂΩïÁöÑ‰øÆÊîπ„ÄÅÁêÜËß£È°πÁõÆÊï¥‰ΩìÊû∂ÊûÑÊó∂ÔºåÂçïÁ∫ØÁöÑËá™Âä®Ë°•ÂÖ®‰æøÊòæÂæóÂäõ‰∏ç‰ªéÂøÉ„ÄÇÂÆÉÁöÑÊú¨Ë¥®Ôºå‰ªçÊòØ‰∏ÄÁßçÂü∫‰∫éÂ±ÄÈÉ®‰ø°ÊÅØÁöÑÈ´òÂ∫¶‰ºòÂåñÁöÑÂ∫èÂàóÈ¢ÑÊµãÔºåËÄåÈùûÂØπÊï¥‰∏™Â∑•Á®ãÁöÑÊ∑±Â∫¶ÁêÜËß£„ÄÇÂºÄÂèëËÄÖÈúÄË¶ÅÁöÑÔºå‰∏çÂÜçÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™‰ªÖ‰ªÖËÉΩË°•ÂÖ®‰ª£Á†ÅÁöÑÂä©ÊâãÔºåËÄåÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™ËÉΩÂ§üÁêÜËß£Â§çÊùÇÊåá‰ª§„ÄÅËá™‰∏ªËßÑÂàíÂπ∂ÊâßË°åÂ§öÊ≠•‰ªªÂä°ÁöÑ‚ÄúË°åÂä®ËÄÖ‚Äù„ÄÇËøô‰æøÊòØ AI Êô∫ËÉΩ‰ΩìËØûÁîüÁöÑÂøÖÁÑ∂„ÄÇ

ËøôÊ≠£ÊòØ‚Äú‰∏ä‰∏ãÊñáÂ∑•Á®ã‚ÄùÂèñ‰ª£‚ÄúÊèêÁ§∫ËØçÂ∑•Á®ã‚ÄùÊàê‰∏∫Ê†∏ÂøÉËÆÆÈ¢òÁöÑÂéüÂõ†„ÄÇÊèêÁ§∫ËØçÂ∑•Á®ãÔºåÊú¨Ë¥®‰∏äÊòØ‰∏ÄÁßç‰∏éÊ®°Âûã‚ÄúÁåúË∞ú‚ÄùÁöÑËâ∫ÊúØÔºåÊàë‰ª¨ËØïÂõæÁî®Á≤æÂ∑ßÁöÑËØ≠Ë®ÄËØ±ÂØºÊ®°ÂûãÁªôÂá∫ÊúüÊúõÁöÑÁ≠îÊ°à„ÄÇËÄå‰∏ä‰∏ãÊñáÂ∑•Á®ãÔºåÂàôÊòØ‰∏ÄÁßçÊûÑÂª∫‰ø°ÊÅØÁéØÂ¢ÉÁöÑÁßëÂ≠¶ÔºåÂÆÉÊõ¥ÂÖ≥Ê≥®‰∫é‰∏∫Ê®°ÂûãÊèê‰æõ‰∏Ä‰∏™È´òË¥®Èáè„ÄÅÈ´ò‰ø°Âô™ÊØîÁöÑ‰ø°ÊÅØÂú∫„ÄÇÂú®Ëøô‰∏™‰ø°ÊÅØÂú∫‰∏≠ÔºåÊ®°Âûã‰∏çÂÜçÈúÄË¶ÅÂéª‚ÄúÁåú‚ÄùÔºåËÄåÊòØËÉΩÂ§üÂü∫‰∫éÂÖÖÂàÜÁöÑ‰æùÊçÆÂéª‚ÄúÊé®ÁêÜ‚ÄùÂíå‚ÄúÂÜ≥Á≠ñ‚Äù„ÄÇÊ≠£Â¶Ç‰∏Ä‰Ωç‰ºòÁßÄÁöÑÊåáÊå•ÂÆòÔºåÂÖ∂ÂÜ≥Á≠ñÁöÑË¥®ÈáèÂπ∂ÈùûÂèñÂÜ≥‰∫éÂëΩ‰ª§ÂñäÂæóÂ§ö‰πàÂìç‰∫ÆÔºåËÄåÊòØÊ∫ê‰∫éÂÖ∂ÂØπÊàòÂú∫ÂÖ®Â±Ä‰ø°ÊÅØÁöÑÁ≤æÂáÜÊéåÊè°„ÄÇÂØπ‰∫é AI Êô∫ËÉΩ‰ΩìËÄåË®ÄÔºå‚Äú‰∏ä‰∏ãÊñá‚ÄùÂ∞±ÊòØÂÆÉÁöÑÊï¥‰∏™ÊàòÂú∫„ÄÇ

result.text:
Announcing my new course: Agentic AI!

Building AI agents is one of the most in-demand skills in the job market. This course, available now at https://t.co/zGHUh1loPO, teaches you how.

You'll learn to implement four key agentic design patterns:
- Reflection, in which an agent examines its own output and figures out how to improve it
- Tool use, in which an LLM-driven application decides which functions to call to carry out web search, access calendars, send email, write code, etc.
- Planning, where you'll use an LLM to decide how to break down a task into sub-tasks for execution, and
- Multi-agent collaboration, in which you build multiple specialized agents ‚Äî much like how a company might hire multiple employees ‚Äî to perform a complex task

You'll also learn to take a complex application and systematically decompose it into a sequence of tasks to implement using these design patterns.

But here's what I think is the most important part of this course: Having worked with many teams on AI agents, I've found that the single biggest predictor of whether someone executes well is their ability to drive a disciplined process for evals and error analysis. In this course, you'll learn how to do this, so you can efficiently home in on which components to improve in a complex agentic workflow. Instead of guessing what to work on, you'll let evals data guide you. This will put you significantly ahead of the game compared to the vast majority of teams building agents.

Together, we'll build a deep research agent that searches, synthesizes, and reports, using all of these agentic design patterns and best practices.

This self-paced course is taught in a vendor neutral way, using raw Python - without hiding details in a framework. You'll see how each step works, and learn the core concepts that you can then implement using any popular agentic AI framework, or using no framework. The only prerequisite is familiarity with Python, though knowing a bit about LLMs helps.

Come join me, and let's build some agentic AI systems!

Sign up to get started: https://t.co/FX35dloqw4
